content.webTitle: Classical review: Rafał Blechacz, Wigmore Hall, London

fields.headline: Rafał Blechacz
fields.bodyText: Ever since he walked away with all the prizes in the 2005 Chopin Competition in Warsaw at the age of 20, Rafał Blechacz has been hailed as the next bright star in the pianistic firmament. That Blechacz is highly talented there is no doubt, but on the evidence of his latest London appearance he has still a good way to go before he can be mentioned in the same breath as his Polish compatriots such as Zimerman and Anderszewski. What is missing is a real musical personality, that priceless ability to give whatever he plays a distinctive stamp. Blechacz offers enthusiasm, energy and a decent technique; what he doesn't have is a beautiful piano sound or much variation in it, and nothing he played in this recital had any real sense of revelation. There is a likable warmth and directness to his playing, though, and the way he launched into Bach's Italian Concerto to begin had a disarmingly honest quality. The Bach was the most impressive item in the first half. The Mozart sonata that followed, K570 in B flat, was all a bit too well-mannered, and Szymanowski's beefy Variations in B flat minor, which began like lugubrious Brahms and ended like overwrought Chopin, struggled for coherence, though it would be unfair to entirely blame Blechacz. A sequence of Chopin occupied the second half. If the Op 62 nocturnes and Op 17 mazurkas at its centre were robbed of their magic by a particularly fidgety Wigmore audience, the A flat major Ballade and A flat Polonaise flanking them at least had some dramatic presence, though there was no real edge of excitement to either.
